EUROPE’S PERSPECTIVE: THE CAR TARIFFS ARE COMING: There appears to be a growing consensus across the Atlantic that tariffs on exports of cars and car parts to the U.S. are on their way, our colleagues at POLITICO Pro Europe report. Bernd Lange, the European Parliament’s trade committee chairman, said American officials told him that “thunder is coming” if Brussels does not bow to American trade demands such as agriculture and car quotas.

Lange said the main priority of Trump’s trade policy, besides cracking down on China, was the “breaking down of global value chains and the relocation of production in the U.S.,” which is particularly relevant to the automotive industry.

“This will also be reflected in their negotiating interests” with Brussels, Lange warned. “This can’t be accepted by the European Union.”

EU TAKES METAL TARIFFS FIGHT TO THE WTO: Brussels is also hard-pressed on challenging Trump’s duties on steel and aluminum at the World Trade Organization, even if such a move would risk provoking an existential crisis for the global trading body. More here.

KOCH GROUP LAUNCHES THANKSGIVING CAMPAIGN TO OPPOSE TARIFFS: Americans for Prosperity, a pro-free trade Koch network group, launched a mail campaign this week to urge a bipartisan group of lawmakers to oppose the Trump administration’s tariffs. The group is sending cards encouraging Americans to call certain lawmakers to ask them “to support U.S. jobs by opposing harmful tariffs and supporting American trade.” The campaign targets Sens. Tim Scott (R-S.C.), Doug Jones (D-Ala.) and Patty Murray (D-Wash.) and Reps. Collin Peterson (D-Minn.) and Will Hurd (R-Texas). AFP is also offering thanks to a group of more than 20 lawmakers who “have held their ground against” the tariffs.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

— Tension between Vice President Mike Pence and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC summit over the weekend shows that Beijing should be preparing for tough talks ahead of the meeting with Trump at the G-20, the South China Morning Post reports.

— A new paper shows China is paying for most of Trump’s trade war, Bloomberg reports.

— Qatar is ramping up a trade dispute against Saudi Arabia over an alleged intellectual property violation, Reuters reports.

— Despite the trade war, U.S. companies don’t appear to be in a hurry to leave China, CNBC reports.

LISA SUENNEN’S TRENDS TO TRACK: Venture capital investor Lisa Suennen has spent more than a decade predicting the future of health technology. But her new role heading Manatt, Phelps and Phillips’ venture capital fund is more complex: applying what she’s learned to areas such as financial technology, digital media and education. POLITICO chatted with Suennen, formerly of GE Ventures, about her current health tech interests, including voice-controlled health assistants, venture-backed primary care businesses, and what major health deals such as the CVS-Aetna acquisition could mean for patients. Pros can read our Q&A here.

FDA ROLLS OUT NEW RX-USE-APP PAPER: Many apps that offer information about prescription drug use wouldn’t require FDA approval before going on the market, the agency proposed in a new concept paper Monday.

Apps offering or tracking basic information, such as symptom trackers, wouldn’t require agency pre-approval, but would need to meet post-market requirements for promotional drug labeling. But apps offering significant changes to clinical outcomes would likely require more review. The agency thinks most of these apps would fit the former category.

Products that have already been reviewed by the agency’s device center likely wouldn’t face scrutiny from the drug office.

Developers had long griped about differences in standards between the agency’s drug and device offices, and the proposal — a prelude to later draft guidance — addresses that.

Bradley Merrill Thompson of Epstein, Becker and Green said he was glad the agency was starting to address the subject, but he still expressed significant reservations. The proposal only covers apps developed by drug sponsors in conjunction with their products, and Thompson says that independent companies need attention too.

“It is, though, nice to see the agency start to publish anything on software used with pharmaceutical products,” he wrote. “We just hope that we will see more soon.” Pros can read Darius’s story on the topic here.

...Speaking of apps, Pear Therapeutics and Novartis on Monday announced the commercial launch of an app they say is the first FDA-authorized prescription digital therapeutic intended to help with the treatment of substance use disorder. The app, called reSET, would let patients report their cravings and triggers to their clinicians before their in-person meetings.

REP. WILL HURD CLINCHES REELECTION: Republican Rep. Will Hurd, a leading congressional voice on tech policy issues, secured reelection in his Texas border district as his Democratic challenger Gina Ortiz Jones conceded defeat following two weeks of uncertainty about the outcome, our POLITICO colleague Cristiano Lima reports.

As chair of the House Oversight and Government Reform subcommittee on information technology, Hurd has called for the government to upgrade its aging computer systems and modernize its approach to AI. He has also been a major advocate for bolstering federal cybersecurity.

Last April, Hurd introduced a bill, H.R. 2227 (115) aimed at creating a fund to boost federal IT investment. It was eventually included in a defense measure, H.R. 2810 (115), which was signed into law by President Donald Trump last year.

Hurd was initially declared the winner by the Associated Press on election night, but a few hours later AP withdrew the call, saying the vote count for Jones was "higher than anticipated."

...Elsewhere on the Hill, Colorado Rep. Diana DeGette has withdrawn her bid for Democratic whip, our Playbook colleagues report. South Carolina Rep. Jim Clyburn is now the only candidate seeking that post. DeGette was a key architect of the 21st Century Cures Act.

HEALTH IT BUSINESS WATCH

NOTABLE AMAZON HEALTH VENTURE HIRE: The health venture led by Atul Gawande is getting a health data expert focused on improving patient health. CNBC reports Dana Gelb Safran, who was leading performance measurement and improvement at Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, is joining the new, still-undefined health venture formed by Amazon, JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway.

...In other tech leadership news, the head of a major technology lobbying organization whose members include Amazon and IBM is defecting to Netflix, our POLITICO colleague Steven Overly reports. Dean Garfield is exiting the Information Technology Industry Council after nearly 10 years as president and CEO, creating a key vacancy at one of the tech sector's largest trade associations during a tumultuous time for the industry.

ITI has been a prominent voice in tech policy battles, which will only heat up next year as lawmakers look to hold the industry to account on issues like protecting user data. Under Garfield, ITI has sought to align companies around consumer privacy principles that could underpin federal legislation, a difficult task as members like Facebook, Google, Apple and IBM have taken divergent stances.

Those principles, including giving consumers more control over data, were released last month and will be key industry talking points as it urges Congress to create rules that override state privacy laws, including a California law taking effect in 2020.

ITI has also opposed Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods, which the association argues punishes tech companies that import parts and products. The group aggressively backed Trump's tax reform efforts last year, however, which delivered a windfall for companies that repatriated cash held overseas.

REWARDING REUSE: The Wellcome Trust, a biomedical research charity, is handing out cash to groups who can generate new insight from information already available in open databases. The first prizes will be for insights related to antimicrobial resistance and malaria. Sage Bionetworks is also partnering with Wellcome on the re-use contest.

STUDY TO EXAMINE PREGNANT WOMENS’ SMARTPHONE USE: The National Science Foundation has given the University of Texas at Austin a $1.2 million grant to study the smartphone habits of 1,000 pregnant women, hoping the data will help create individualized care plans. Participants will download an app that gathers data about their movement, social network interactions, screen time and typing speed. Kelly Gaither, an associate professor of women’s health at UT-Austin’s Dell Medical School, said researchers could also track changes in speech and sleep patterns and link them to medical outcomes.

With help from Eric Geller and Martin Matishak

THE COZY BEAR CHRONICLES — Another company, Google cybersecurity offshoot Chronicle, has identified a series of phishing attacks as bearing similarities to past attacks by the Russian government-affiliated hacking group APT29, also known as Cozy Bear. Brandon Levene, head of applied intelligence, found via Google online file scanning service VirusTotal that the tactics the new campaign uses are identical — down to the metadata — to those attributed to the group in 2016, the year Cozy Bear allegedly was involved in hacking the Democratic National Committee.

While FireEye’s details about a State Department campaign have drawn the most media attention, Levene found another element of the campaign noteworthy. “If the reports that media is a target are true, it would be interesting and could show that attackers are attempting to observe and manipulate news cycles,” he said via email. “For instance, attackers would have advance notice of news stories and could prepare social media posts to go out when the news hits that could discredit the news or otherwise manipulate it.” He also predicted the group would return with more sophisticated tactics because this campaign was discovered so quickly.

Chronicle joins CrowdStrike, Kaspersky Lab and FireEye as companies pointing out the apparent connections to APT29, with varying degrees of confidence. FireEye released additional details on the attack campaign Monday. “Analysis of this activity is ongoing, but if the APT29 attribution is strengthened, it would be the first activity uncovered from this sophisticated group in at least a year,” the company wrote in a blog post. “Given the widespread nature of the targeting, organizations that have previously been targeted by APT29 should take note of this activity.” That it could be part of a broader deceptive campaign, planned at least a month in advance, makes it all the more concerning, according to FireEye.

IT’S THE MOST ATTACKFUL TIME OF THE YEAR — Cyber Monday and online shopping for the holiday season are just around the corner, which brings danger from cybercriminals. "It goes without saying that amongst the excitement of a bargain, cybersecurity is not top of mind for consumers, however, it is this type of distraction that opens shoppers up to multiple risks," Rusty Carter, vice president of product management for Arxan, writes via email. "With many of our high-street shops closing down, it is clear that online and mobile shopping is continuing to gain momentum." Carter points to fake apps and cybercrime organizations like Magecart as particular threats.

A trend in past years, expected to continue this year, is the uptick in web skimming activity — that is, segments of malicious code injected into eCommerce website checkout pages to steal customer information, said Kimberly Goody, manager of cybercrime analysis at FireEye. "Underground forums have only exacerbated the proliferation of these operations by providing an outlet for cybercriminals to buy and sell tools (e.g. 'sniffers') and access to eCommerce sites. There have even been recent affiliate offerings geared toward this specific type of activity," she said. Consumers already are getting Thanksgiving-themed spam emails advertising sales. Retailers, meanwhile, should be on the lookout for ransomware and distributed denial of service attacks, she said.

DIVIDE BY ZERO — Devices infected with botnets need to be brought down as close to zero as possible, two researchers argue in a report from the Council on Foreign Relations released Monday — contrary to the “conventional wisdom” that botnets have to be managed rather than shut down entirely. A country can easily harness millions of botnets for geopolitical purposes, such as using DDOS attacks to shutdown large portions of the internet, the report states. Even a small percentage of infected devices, they argue, have “enormous disruptive potential.” Countries should create “botnet goals” such as establishing an international organization to take down botnets, they said. Nations should be held liable for harm caused by botnets within their borders and develop incentives for ISPs to clean up their networks.

CYBERSECURITY FOR SECURITIES — The securities market is a particularly vulnerable segment of the banking and payments industries, according to an analysis of cyber threats out Monday from BAE Systems and the SWIFT financial system. “This is due to the large numbers of Participants and infrastructures in that market, the complexities of their interactions, and inherent characteristics such as long chains of custody, unstructured communications and trusted practice — all of which combine to provide opportunities for APT groups to exploit,” the analysis states, referencing “advanced persistent threat” groups usually tied to nation states.

RUSSIA

TALKING ABOUT TROLLS — Contrary to public belief, most tweets by Russian trolls in the lead-up to the 2016 presidential election did not lead to shady fake-news websites, according to new research. Instead, so-called junk news sites accounted for only 6 percent of links in Internet Research Agency tweets, while legitimate local and regional news sites accounted for 30 percent of links.

“But the number of links to junk news sites spiked sharply in the weeks immediately leading up to the election, suggesting that the trolls put extra effort into spreading falsehoods just before Election Day,” wrote the New York University researchers who conducted the study. The researchers said they suspected that the Russian trolls relied on local news websites because of data showing that Americans overwhelmingly trusted such sources. Another possibility, they said, was that local-news-sharing accounts were “sleeper accounts” meant to develop a legitimate reputation to increase their “effectiveness in future influence campaigns.”

OUT OF OFFICE — Some Microsoft Office 365 and Azure users got an unwelcome surprise on Monday when they found themselves unable to log in to their services. The tech giant told customers they “may be unable to sign in using multi-factor authorization” and “may also be unable to carry out self-service password resets” during the global outage that lasted much of the day. Thus far, no explanation has been given as to why the services went down; Microsoft is likely still investigating, although it applied a patch.

RECENTLY ON PRO CYBERSECURITY — Rep. Will Hurd, top Republican on the House Oversight IT subcommittee,secured his reelection after Gina Ortiz Jones conceded. … Senate Democrats sued to keep Matt Whitaker from taking the job of acting attorney general. … Defense ministers in 25 EU countries launched a joint spy school, an electronic warfare capability project and other defense coordination efforts.

He will focus on the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, an area where he specialized in his previous job as principal analyst and director for transnational risk at Centra Technology.

SHOOTING DEATHS, FIRES ROCK SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA CAMPUSES: A student at Pepperdine University and a recent graduate at Cal Lutheran were among the 12 people slain Nov. 7 at a bar in Thousand Oaks, Calif. About 24 hours later, massive fires swept the area.

— Pepperdine was hit especially hard. The Malibu campus opted to shelter in place during a particularly intense period as fires raged nearby. Nearly 80 students and faculty lost their homes.

— The presidents of both universities say their campuses continue to grieve. At Cal Lutheran, President Chris Kimball told Morning Education that in addition to losing Justin Meek, an intensely popular recent grad, at least 30 students from his university were in the bar during the shooting and some sustained minor injuries. “There is a sense of loss of innocence out here by this happening,” Kimball said.

— In many ways, the fires provided a distraction, Kimball said. A campus gym became a Red Cross shelter location for fire evacuees, and students and faculty volunteered making peanut butter sandwiches for those in need. The university has hired more counselors and is rethinking security precautions.

— Trying to relieve stress, campus leaders have brought in puppies for students to play with, miniature horses and food trucks. “That grieving process has been a little bit delayed. It’s going to happen and probably be even more difficult than it normally would be,” Kimball said. “So we’re very attentive to try to find ways to try to bring the community together.”

— Andrew Benton, president of Pepperdine, said the campus was stunned by the death of student Alaina Housley. He said Housley was an accomplished student and vocalist whose parents also went to Pepperdine. “To have her life taken from us that way, it’s just been very hard for us to process — particularly students 18, 19, 20 years of age who have never experienced anything like this, and I hope they never will again,” Benton said. “We’re trying to help them process and at the same time process our own grief.”

— As the campus mourned, the fires closed in. Benton described how students were called to two separate locations to shelter in place with breathing masks, food and other supplies. “It served us well, but the moments were indeed frightening,” he said.

— To assist with the community’s recovery, the university is working with a local grocery store to offer a Thanksgiving meal on campus. Its law school is providing free legal assistance to residents needing help with insurance or other fire-related paperwork. Pepperdine also created a fund where people can donate to help students and faculty affected by the fires.

— Benton said the campus will host a memorial service for Housley on Nov. 28. “The healing, I think, has begun, but it will be a very important moment of healing,” he said.

PUSH TO RENAME SCHOOL HONORING BEN CARSON CRITICIZED: Members of a group representing conservative African-Americans are condemning an effort underway to rename a Detroit school that honors HUD Secretary Ben Carson, a surgeon and Detroit native. The Project 21 Black Leadership Network called it a “purely political act” that “willfully ignores the accomplishments and charitable acts” by Carson.

— The Benjamin Carson High School of Science and Medicine — a science and medicine-themed school — was intended to honor Carson before he joined President Donald Trump’s Cabinet, according to the Detroit Free Press. Last week, the Detroit Board of Education voted 6-1 to approve a process for seeking new names, but the newspaper reports that the vote doesn’t guarantee the name will change. The vote means the process of seeking input from stakeholders will begin.

FLORIDA SCHOOL SAFETY COMMISSION SEEKS TO BOLSTER FUNDS FOR ARMED GUARDS: The commission in Florida investigating the Parkland school shooting that left 17 dead on Feb. 14 wants the state to give school districts more money to pay for armed guards. It is also proposing a statewide formula to determine how many security personnel are needed for each campus.

— The commission, in a draft report obtained by POLITICO through a records request, also wants the state to increase law enforcement's access to student records and school facilities, and to strengthen communication between agencies. The 99-page document includes dozens of recommendations of varying cost and detail, each drawing on discussions between commissioners who have met over the last few months. A final report must be sent to state lawmakers by Jan. 1. Read more from POLITICO Pro Florida’s Andrew Atterbury.

VETERANS' EDUCATION

WYOMING SENATOR QUESTIONS VA’S HANDLING OF GI BILL CLAIMS: Mike Enzi (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, is the latest lawmaker to criticize the Veterans Affairs Department’s handling of GI Bill claims. In a letter to the VA, he notes that since Aug. 1, hundreds of thousands of veterans have either not received their monthly housing allowance for the fall 2018 semester or received an incorrect amount as the agency struggles to implement changes made by Congress to the GI Bill last year.

— Enzi wants to know how much the VA has spent on the IT problems that continue to plague the agency. He also wants to know how long it will be before the VA reimburses recipients who have not been receiving the correct housing allowance while the department works to correct processing problems.

— Last week, VA officials testified on Capitol Hill that it’s not clear when the problem will be fixed — although they emphasized it’s a priority.

— Soon after, Stars and Stripes reported that the VA official leading the implementation of the GI Bill expansion, Robert Worley, is being reassigned to a regional office in Texas.

REPORT ROLL CALL

— The Bipartisan Policy Center says in a new “early learning facilities policy framework” that more attention needs to be focused on improving the facilities that house young children. This includes child care centers, family child care homes, Head Start facilities and part-day preschools. Read it here.

— UNESCO’s 2019 Global Education Monitoring Report released today finds that the number of migrant and refugee school-age children around the world has grown by 26 percent since 2000 and could fill half a million classrooms.

SYLLABUS

— Former Missouri school chief seeking old job: St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

— North Carolina educator’s advice about “culturally appropriate” Thanksgiving raises eyebrows: The News & Observer.

— Harvard senior becomes first DACA recipient to win Rhodes Scholarship: Harvard Crimson.

— In most U.S. cities, neighborhoods have grown more integrated. Their schools haven’t: Chalkbeat.

— North Carolina school with major chickenpox outbreak has high vaccination exemption rate: Asheville Citizen Times.

— “Hateful and disrespectful emails” spur message from Kentucky education commissioner: Lexington Herald-Leader.

— Some community college students in New Jersey will soon be eligible for SNAP benefits: POLITICO Pro New Jersey.

title: Cell-based meat issue could still be settled on the Hill
description: Farm bill clock runs down — Hundreds of trade-aid recipients live the urban life
content: With help from Catherine Boudreau, Sarah Zimmerman, Helena Bottemiller Evich and Megan Cassella Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access to the ne… [+11704 chars]
fulltext:
Cell-based meat issue could still be settled on the Hill

With help from Catherine Boudreau, Sarah Zimmerman, Helena Bottemiller Evich and Megan Cassella

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Agriculture will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22, and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next Morning Ag installment will publish on Monday, Nov. 26.

IN THE HOPPER: Key lawmakers with power over USDA and FDA spending want more information on the two agencies’ plan to divide up jurisdiction over cell-cultured meat before they’ll consider nixing a provision in an upcoming funding bill that would give USDA lead responsibility over the budding sector.

— Trade aid and city life: USDA records show that trade aid payments have been made to hundreds of people who live in urban areas. The Environmental Working Group said it’s evidence that the next farm bill should tighten payment limits for farm subsidies.

— Pressure building for tariff deal with Mexico, Canada: The new North American trade agreement is in line to be signed at the end of next week, but Mexico and Canada want relief from U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum by then.

CELL-BASED MEAT ISSUE COULD STILL BE SETTLED ON THE HILL: USDA and FDA ended their turf war over cell-cultured meat by announcing they have agreed to split up jurisdiction of the burgeoning industry — but the issue has not been fully resolved. Some members of Congress haven’t yet backed off from their efforts to dictate regulatory control of the products, Helena Bottemiller Evich reports this morning.

A rider tucked into next year’s agriculture spending bill would mandate that USDA lead oversight of cell-based products. The White House had urged the Hill to drop the provision and leave it up to USDA and FDA to figure it out, but lawmakers have not backed down. Appropriators have until Dec. 7 to pass the ag spending package for fiscal 2019.

‘Talk is cheap’: Some lawmakers, such as Rep. Robert Aderholt, who chairs the Appropriations subcommittee on agriculture, are holding firm. The Alabama Republican wants to learn more about what the divided jurisdiction would look like before making a call on whether to jettison the rider, a spokesperson told Helena.

“As I have seen over the years when jurisdictional battles brew, that talk is cheap when written words matter,” the spokesperson said.

On the Senate side, John Hoeven, head of the Appropriations panel on agriculture, is also gathering more information to “ensure that the agreement works,” according to his spokesperson. Livestock groups have aggressively pushed for USDA to take the lead in regulation, and Hoeven took heat previously for not strongly supporting the rider from the start.

Pros, read Helena’s story here.

HAPPY TUESDAY, NOV. 20! Welcome to Morning Ag, where your host is astounded by the scope of the California fires. Taken together, the three fires encompass an area equal to 17 Manhattans. Send news and tips to lcrampton@politico.com and @liz_crampton, and follow the whole team @Morning_Ag.

POLITICO Pro PROVIDES DEDICATED CALIFORNIA COVERAGE: There is a new authority on California politics and policy. Just in time to help policy professionals and business leaders in the Golden State navigate the twists and turns of a new administration, POLITICO California Pro is the only tool that will arm you with a team of state-level experts. Learn more.

FARM BILL CLOCK RUNS DOWN: House and Senate agriculture leaders and their staff continued negotiations Monday, trading offers and insisting they’re getting close to a final deal. With lawmakers out of town this week for the Thanksgiving holiday, updates have been few and far between.

Time is of the essence: MA readers are well aware that negotiators don’t have much time to make a deal and get the details wrapped up so Congress can move in early December. Significant policy tweaks at this stage will also need new CBO scores (not the easiest thing to accomplish the week of Thanksgiving).

Abraham blames Democrats: Rep. Ralph Abraham (R-La.), a member of the House Agriculture Committee, on Monday accused House Democrats of trying to delay farm bill talks to punt the issue to the next Congress. "We can ram this through, and I think that's what we've got to do at this time,” he told a local outlet. A spokesperson for House Agriculture Chairman Mike Conaway did not respond to an inquiry about whether he agrees with Abraham.

HUNDREDS OF TRADE-AID RECIPIENTS LIVE THE URBAN LIFE: The Environmental Working Group’s release Monday of early USDA data on the tariff-relief package showed that more than 87,700 direct payments were made to individuals and farm entities through Oct. 31 — and that 1,142 of those recipients reside in some of the nation’s largest cities, Pro Ag’s Catherine Boudreau reports. The average payment to city dwellers was $881.

The advocacy group, a longtime critic of farm subsidies, used its analysis of records obtained through a FOIA request to renew its calls for Congress and the Trump administration to tighten payment limits in the next farm bill.

Qualifying for subsidies: Aid should be going to “actual” farmers who have been hit by retaliatory tariffs due to President Donald Trump’s trade policies and not to those who have little role in agriculture, said Scott Faber, the group’s senior vice president of government affairs.

A USDA spokesperson said that in order to be eligible for trade assistance, individuals must meet the department’s “actively engaged” criteria for subsidies — or contribute significant capital to an agricultural operation, or provide land and equipment, labor, or management. The same eligibility standard is also applied across commodity support programs in the farm bill. Unlike those commodity programs, however, a producer also has to prove actual production of a crop to qualify for trade aid, the spokesperson said.

EWG and other critics of farm subsidies argue that USDA’s definition of “actively engaged” is rife with loopholes that allow non-farmers, like people living in cities, to collect payments.

THE ADAGE “WORK HARD AND GET AHEAD” is a waning reality in America today. The question is: What can Washington do to foster more opportunity and prosperity in struggling communities across the country? POLITICO convened a bipartisan group of 14 business leaders, thinkers and policymakers to explore the problem and identify solutions that have a realistic path forward with political leaders of both parties. Read the latest issue of The Agenda to learn more.

TARIFF DEAL BY DECEMBER? MEXICO, CANADA HOPE SO: A top Mexican official said Mexico and Canada expect to reach a deal with the Trump administration to lift U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum by the time the three nations sign the new North American trade agreement at the G-20 summit in Buenos Aires at the end of next week.

“It is the expectation that by the time of the signing, there will be either a solution or a very clear track that gives enough certainty to all parties that a solution is coming,” Mexican Ambassador Gerónimo Gutiérrez told reporters Monday, Pro Trade’s Doug Palmer reports.

A deal would clear the way for Canada and Mexico to lift retaliatory duties on about $15 billion worth of U.S. exports, including several agricultural products.

Ag, business groups join push for pre-signing deal: Gutierrez’s comments came the same day that nearly three dozen prominent agricultural, business and manufacturing groups, including the National Pork Producers Council, wrote to U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to urge him to remove steel and aluminum duties against Canada and Mexico before the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement is signed.

The groups warned that failure to do so would jeopardize the pact’s chances of passing in Congress. More here.

USDA INTERVENED IN 4-H LGBT POLICY DEBATE: Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue’s former chief of staff pressured the national 4-H youth program to withdraw a policy welcoming members that identify as LGBT, according to a Des Moines Register investigation.

The 4-H organization, which is administered by the National Institute of Food and Agriculture, circulated the policy among at least eight state chapters, some of which posted it online. A few days after it was published earlier this year, Heidi Green, Perdue’s chief of staff at the time, asked for it to be rescinded, according to Sonny Ramaswamy, NIFA’s director at the time. Green left USDA in May to return home to Georgia.

The policy, intended to expand LGBT membership and modernize the organization, caused a rift among some 4-H volunteers and outside conservative and evangelical groups, the Register reported. It also led to the firing of the Iowa 4-H director, John-Paul Chaisson-Cárdenas, who had advocated for the policy.

USDA’s response: “The document in question was developed by a regional 4-H leadership group, did not set national 4-H policy, and should not have been disseminated,” a spokesperson said in a statement, adding that “decisions on such topics rightly belong on the local level.”

ROW CROPS

— Kudlow on life as a free-trader in Trump world: Larry Kudlow, Trump’s top economic adviser, talks with POLITICO’s Ben White about progress he’s made in pushing a free-trade message in the White House (think NAFTA 2.0) and the clashes with more hawkish, pro-tariff forces in the administration. Listen to the latest POLITICO Money podcast.

— Criminal justice reformers frustrated with hemp ban for felons: Hemp farmers are eagerly awaiting potential passage of a farm bill that contains a provision from Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell that would legalize hemp, a boon for the industry. But a late addition that would also ban people convicted of drug felonies from growing hemp has angered lawmakers, hemp industry participants and religious groups who view it as a punishment to minorities. James Higdon writes for POLITICO Magazine here.

— Lobbying push geared to RFS reset: EPA’s impending reconsideration of how much biofuels must be blended into the gasoline supply may provide the American Petroleum Institute with a lobbying opening on Capitol Hill, Pro Energy’s Eric Wolff reports. The forthcoming plan gives an opportunity for Renewable Fuel Standard reforms that have struggled to gain support in Congress.

— EPA’s chemical office nominee gets a hearing: Alexandra Dunn, Trump’s nominee to lead EPA’s chemical safety office, will receive a confirmation hearing before the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee on Nov. 29. Pro Energy’s Annie Snider has more.

— NASS collecting year-end data: USDA’s National Agricultural Statistics Services is gathering year-end crop production numbers and the amount of grain and oilseeds producers are storing on their farms. That information, collected annually, will be published early next year. The Leader-Telegram has more.

— Life in a California fire evacuation zone: Jeff Evans is one of the few residents who stuck around in a mandatory evacuation zone due to the Camp Fire. He spends his time saving animals and checking on neighbors’ properties. The Los Angeles Times has the story of his rescues here.

— Movers and shakers: Madelyn Rabenhorst has joined the Soil Health Partnership, an initiative of the National Corn Growers Association, as a South Dakota field manager, the group announced Monday. Stacey Stiens is already serving as program coordinator in the state.

THAT’S ALL FOR MA! See you right here tomorrow. In the meantime, drop us a line: cboudreau@politico.com and @ceboudreau; rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon; hbottemiller@politico.com and @hbottemiller; lcrampton@politico.com and @liz_crampton; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny.

You can also follow @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Ag on Twitter.

Trump asylum restrictions blocked

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Shift will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22 and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next Morning Shift newsletter will publish on Monday, Nov. 26. Please continue to follow PRO Employment & Immigration issues here.

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Shift is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Employment & Immigration subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

With help from Ian Kullgren, Timothy Noah and Daniel Lippman

TRUMP ASYLUM RESTRICTIONS BLOCKED: Late Monday night a San Francisco federal district court temporarily blocked the Trump administration's moves earlier this month to deny asylum to migrants who cross the border illegally. "Whatever the scope of the President’s authority, he may not rewrite the immigration laws to impose a condition that Congress has expressly forbidden," Judge Jon Tigar says in the order. "Asylum seekers will be put at increased risk of violence and other harms at the border, and many will be deprived of meritorious asylum claims," he said.

Tigar's ruling in East Bay Sanctuary Covenant v. Trump, is a win for immigrants, halting implementation of a fast-track regulation and presidential proclamation issued Nov. 9 that barred migrants who cross the border between ports of entry from seeking asylum. Read the order here and more on the executive actions here.

GOOD TUESDAY MORNING! It’s Nov. 20, and this is Morning Shift, POLITICO's daily tipsheet on employment and immigration policy. Send tips, exclusives, and suggestions to rrainey@politico.com, thesson@politico.com, ikullgren@politico.com and tnoah@politico.com. Follow us on Twitter at @RebeccaARainey, @tedhesson, @IanKullgren and @TimothyNoah1.

Learn more.

AT THE BORDER

BORDER PULLBACK: Meanwhile, the Pentagon will start pulling back the 5,800 troops stationed along the Southwest border as soon as this week, POLITICO’s Wesley Morgan reports. “The returning service members include engineering and logistics units whose jobs included placing concertina wire and other barriers to limit access to ports of entry at the U.S.-Mexico border,” Morgan writes. According to Army Lt. Gen. Jeffrey Buchanan, who’s overseeing the border operation, the deployment is on track to end Dec. 15.

Caravan migrants from Central America have been arriving for the past week in Tijuana. Early Monday morning, the Border Patrol closed northbound lanes into San Ysidro, Calif. for three hours at the Tijuana port of entry (the busiest in the U.S.) “after @CBP officials were notified that a large # of caravan migrants were planning to rush the border in an attempt to gain illegal access to the US,” Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen tweeted Monday afternoon. The Wall Street Journal quoted a DHS official citing “intelligence reports, including from the Mexican government.”

But Buchanan cast doubt on the severity of the threat, saying that if there were "reliable reports" that a mob was about to rush the border, or something similar that could put agents at risk, "we would close the port.” More from Morgan here, and POLITICO’s Rebecca Rainey on the border closing here, and more from the Journal here.

LAWMAKERS PUSH ON ASYLUM: Rep. Lucille Roybal-Allard (D-Calif), the likely next appropriations chair for the DHS subcommittee, joined Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) in writing President Trump Monday urging him to rescind the presidential actions restricting asylum access at the U.S.-Mexico border, which, they said, “violate domestic and international law.” The Democratic House members said that the policies, combined with the Border Patrol’s “ongoing efforts to meter and turn back asylum seekers at ports of entry along the southern border,” served to “effectively create an asylum ban. Read the letter here.

UNIONS

COLUMBIA CAVES: Columbia University said Monday that it will start bargaining with its graduate student employees union more than two years after the NLRB handed down a precedent-setting ruling that allowed student workers to unionize. Columbia refused to recognize the student union after the 2016 decision, saying it would seek a review in federal appellate court. But the university backed down Monday, facing a Dec. 4 strike deadline, the Columbia Spectator reports.

A framework agreement announced by the university “sets forth mutually agreed upon principles to guide negotiations toward collective bargaining agreements on wages, hours, and other working conditions for Columbia’s student research and teaching assistants and for our diverse postdoc community,” Lee Bollinger, the university president, said in a written statement. Negotiations are expected to begin by late February 2019. More here.

Meanwhile, a 60-percent majority of Brown graduate students voted to unionize, the university announced Monday. Stand Up for Graduate Student Employees and the American Federation of Teachers will represent approximately 900 doctoral and master’s students working as “teaching assistants, research assistants or proctors,” according to a university press release. “This win means a voice for parents who are graduate employees and in need of better childcare, and a voice for international graduate employees facing complicated immigration issues,” AFT President Randi Weingarten said in a separate statement. The actions at Columbia and Brown follow the news earlier this month that Georgetown University graduate students voted overwhelmingly to unionize. Read the press release from Brown here and AFT’s statement here.

REFUGEES GO TO WORK: The Trump administration’s moves to scale back refugee admissions has led to a 74 percent decrease in arrivals, from 85,000 in fiscal year 2016 to 22,500 in fiscal year 2018, according to an issue brief released Monday by the left-leaning Center for American Progress. The new 30,000 cap on refugees that the Trump administration announced in September could reduce that number further. Check out the brief here.

SHARING CENSUS DATA?: “Trump administration officials have privately discussed the possibility that in the future census information could be shared with law enforcement,” the Washington Post’s Tara Bahrampour reported Monday. Or anyway, the officials discussed the possibility of discussing it.

After a May hearing, Rep. Jimmy Gomez (D-Calif.) submitted a written query to the Justice Department seeking reassurance that DOJ continued to interpret the 2001 USA Patriot Act not to override a 1954 law that required the Census Bureau not to share information collected in the census with any other government agency or court. In an email exchange about how to respond, Ben Aguinaga, chief of staff to John Gore, acting assistant attorney general for civil rights, advised Gore, “I don’t think we want to say too much there in case the issues addressed in the [earlier] opinion or related issues come up later for renewed debate.” Gore didn’t appear in the email to be advocating a change so much as noting that someone else (perhaps then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions, whose hawkish immigration views were well known) might do so. Incidentally, NPR Census reporter Hansi Lo Wang tweeted a copy of the document on Saturday. More here.

NEW REFUGEE LEADERSHIP: Scott Lloyd, the Trump administration's controversial refugee office director, may have more time to work on his book about his anti-abortion beliefs.

POLITICO’s Rachana Pradhan reports that the former Knights of Columbus lawyer is being reassigned after fallout from DHS’ lack of preparation for the surge of migrant children it became responsible following Trump’s “zero tolerance policy.”

A top HHS official conducted a “top to bottom” review of the department's handling of the migrant crisis, and senior officials concluded that Lloyd mismanaged aspects of the response, POLITICO reported last month. In one example, “Lloyd told staff to stop keeping a spreadsheet tracking separated families.”

Democrats too have long sought Lloyd's ouster over his efforts to block unaccompanied teens in federal custody from obtaining abortions. His career has been devoted to promoting Catholic causes. The refugee office’s current chief of staff, Jonathan Hayes, will serve as interim director, a spokesperson confirmed to Morning Shift. More here.

Meanwhile over at U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, Kathryn Rexrode is now associate director of external affairs. Previously she was communications director for the House Judiciary Committee.

author: Gabby Orr
title: Immigration hawks fear DOJ staff exodus
description: Several Jeff Sessions' loyalists have either quit or are eyeing the exit as they wait to see who will succeed their former boss.
content: The uncertainty surrounding President Donald Trumps pick for attorney general has left some DOJ staffers feeling as though theyre in limbo. | Zach Gibson/Getty Images The Justice Department is facing a likely senior staff exodus once President Donald Trump ta… [+6620 chars]
fulltext:
The uncertainty surrounding President Donald Trump’s pick for attorney general has left some Justice Department staffers feeling as though they’re in limbo. | Zach Gibson/Getty Images Justice Department Immigration hawks fear DOJ staff exodus Several Jeff Sessions loyalists have either quit or are eyeing the exit as they wait to see who will succeed their former boss.

The Justice Department is facing a likely senior staff exodus once President Donald Trump taps a permanent replacement for ousted Attorney General Jeff Sessions, creating a leadership vacuum that has troubled hard-line immigration activists.

According to more than a half-dozen former and current administration officials, at least four top officials — mostly Sessions loyalists — have either quit or are eyeing the exit as they await Trump’s decision on who will succeed their former boss, who implemented and vigorously defended even Trump’s most controversial immigration policies.

Story Continued Below

Among those leaving are Danielle Cutrona, a senior counsel to Sessions who had been with him since his Senate days. She departed DOJ last Friday. Rachael Tucker, a senior counselor to the attorney general, could also exit “in the next couple of months,” citing her fidelity to Sessions, or possibly take another job within the agency, said two sources close to the situation. Acting Assistant Attorney General Jeff Wood, another former Sessions Senate staffer, may also soon make an exit, according to one senior administration official.

And while the White House could find another strident immigration hawk to lead DOJ and name ideologically similar aides, several of the names being floated for attorney general — such as former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and George H.W. Bush-era Attorney General Bill Barr — represent a more GOP establishment line on the subject.

The most reliable politics newsletter. Sign up for POLITICO Playbook and get the latest news, every morning — in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

It’s a situation that conservatives who support reduced immigration have long feared. Even Trump’s critics concede that Sessions’ staff has dutifully guided the president’s hard-line immigration policies, propped up the president's most contested executive actions and added a record number of adjudicators to U.S. immigration courts. Sessions also made headlines for his defense of the administration’s decision to separate migrant children from parents who have crossed the border illegally.

More recently, Sessions personally guided the White House as Trump attempted to dramatically limit asylum applications, removing some language in the process and ultimately signing off on the new rule, according to two DOJ officials.

“For better or for worse, you cannot say [Sessions] has not had a very profound impact,” said Leon Fresco, head of the DOJ’s Office of Immigration Litigation under President Barack Obama.

“He’s been a guiding force in moving both the DOJ and the Department of Homeland Security to draft and implement some of the most restrictive rules on immigration,” he added.

A DOJ leadership void could leave DHS to take up the immigration mantle, a prospect that worries advocates of stricter border laws, many of whom have been disappointed in current DHS chief Kirstjen Nielsen's performance. While DHS has the power to enforce immigration policies — a topic Trump recently claimed Nielsen could be "much tougher" on — DOJ is the agency that can set uncompromising rules.

And DHS may soon be poised to get a more pugnacious leader on the subject, increasing the chance that the agency asserts itself more on topics like border crossings. Trump is considering replacing Nielsen with Thomas Homan, a tough-talking lawman who once recommended charging so-called sanctuary-city politicians “with crimes.”

“Depending on who is named DHS secretary, some leadership may shift back over to the person in that role,” said Jessica Vaughan, director of policy studies at the conservative Center for Immigration Studies.

Without Sessions and his cohort of aides atop the agency, immigration hard-liners are wondering whether his protégé, senior White House policy adviser Stephen Miller, can stay the course on the administration's effort to remake decades of immigration policy by boosting border enforcement and immigration prosecutions and challenging states that refuse cooperation with federal immigration authorities.

“Everyone involved on immigration issues has witnessed a long list of things that got done" under Sessions, said Vaughan. A fan of Sessions, Vaughan griped about the lack of an “obvious candidate” to take control of the agency if the president wants immigration to continue to be one of its highest-priority issues.

The uncertainty surrounding Trump’s pick for attorney general, combined with growing expectations that the White House won’t announce its nominee until mid-December at the earliest, has left some fifth-floor staffers feeling as though they’re in limbo, wondering whether it’s time to leave the administration or worth the wait to see who takes over as attorney general. Sessions has encouraged his loyalists to stick around to see who might take over for him.

Although Cutrona has already left DOJ, several other senior leaders eyeing the door are expected to stick around long enough to ensure “a smooth transition,” said one senior administration official, who claimed staffers who have been at the agency since Trump’s inauguration are "burnt out." And a DOJ spokesperson said Tucker "plans to stay [and] may take on a different role," though such a move has yet to be finalized or announced.



Matthew Whitaker, Sessions’ former chief of staff, has taken over as acting attorney general, but multiple sources said they doubt Trump will nominate Whitaker to take over permanently. Whitaker’s appointment has also been challenged by Democratic lawmakers and conservative legal scholars, including George Conway, the husband of White House counselor Kellyanne Conway, who argue that Trump illegally evaded the normal DOJ line of succession. The White House has justified its decision by pointing to the Vacancies Reform Act, which allows the president to temporarily fill most empty executive branch positions.

To replace Whitaker, the White House is looking at a slate of candidates. In addition to Christie and Barr, Trump is eyeing Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar, outgoing Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi and Solicitor General Noel Francisco. Mark Filip, a deputy attorney general during the George W. Bush administration, is another option. McClatchy also reported that the White House had discussed the job with Janice Rogers Brown, a retired D.C. circuit judge and former California Supreme Court justice.

“[Sessions] would want them to stay there and do their job if they really enjoy it,” said a source close to the former attorney general, adding that “some are still going to feel that out of a sense of loyalty [they] need to leave.”

title: Schumer demands probe on Whitaker's ties to Trump

content: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer requested that the inspector general provide information on whether Matthew Whitaker provided any assurance to the White House that he would interfere with the Mueller investigation. | Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images S… [+1759 chars]
fulltext:
Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer requested that the inspector general provide information on whether Matthew Whitaker provided any assurance to the White House that he would interfere with the Mueller investigation. | Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images Legal Schumer demands probe on Whitaker's ties to Trump

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) sent a letter Tuesday requesting that the Justice Department inspector general investigate communications between Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker and the White House.

In his letter, Schumer cited news reports of Whitaker’s close relationship with President Donald Trump during his former role as chief of staff to former Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

Story Continued Below

“I am particularly concerned about whether Mr. Whitaker may have shared with the White House, or could share in his new role, confidential grand jury or investigative information from the Special Counsel investigation or any criminal investigation,” Schumer wrote in a letter to Department of Justice Inspector General Michael Horowitz.

Schumer added that disclosure of such information could “implicate criminal contempt of court, obstruction of justice” or violate the Justice Department’s policy on contact with the White House on criminal investigations.

Schumer requested that the inspector general provide information on whether Whitaker had access to confidential information related to special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation when he was chief of staff and whether Whitaker provided any assurance to the White House that he would interfere with the Mueller investigation.

THE BUZZ: HERE COMES TOM -- “Tom Steyer takes step toward 2020 presidential bid,’’ by POLITICO’s Alex Thompson: “If he can’t impeach Donald Trump, he may try to oust the president the old-fashioned way.

-- “The former billionaire investor, climate activist and impeachment agitator Tom Steyer will take several steps toward a 2020 presidential bid Tuesday.

Story Continued Below

-- “That will include a six-figure web ad buy on Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, and Instagram along with a full-page ad in USA Today and other Gannett newspapers outlining a political platform, a revamped TomSteyer.com, and the announcement of five town halls across the country, the first of which will be in the crucial early primary state of South Carolina, according to copies of the ad and platform provided to POLITICO.

-- The first town hall is set for Dec. 4 in Charleston, S.C., and the next will be in Fresno, Calif., sometime in December, according to Aleigha Cavalier, senior communications adviser for TomSteyer.com who also works for Steyer’s climate-focused group NextGen America. There will be one town hall for each of the “5 rights" on Steyer's platform: the right to an equal vote, to clean air and water, to learn with pre-K education through college, to a living wage, and to health. Story.

BUENOS DÍAS, Good TUESDAY morning. Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke is blaming "radical environmentalists" for the forest fires, Nancy Pelosi is fending off a growing challenge — and wanna talk about challenge? Thy name is Facebook.

QUOTE OF THE DAY: “We know the problem. It’s been years of neglect, and in many cases it’s been these radical environmentalists that want nature to take its course. … You know what? This is on them.” -- Just days after telling Gov. Jerry Brown that “it’s not time for finger-pointing” with regard to the California wildfires, Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke tells Breitbart News that ... it’s time for finger pointing.

TWEET OF THE DAY: Cook Political Report national editor Amy Walter @amyewalter: “Incumbent Dems who signed "anti-Pelosi" letter sit in safe seats. They seem to be willing to make vulnerable frosh D's in tough CDs take a vote that could doom their chances of re-election. Also, if those vulnerable D's lose in 2020, D's likely lose the House.”

BONUS TWEET OF THE DAY: @ACLU: "The White House belongs to the public, not the president, and the job of the press is to ask hard questions, not to be polite."

-- Where’s Jerry? Nothing official announced.

-- Where’s Gavin? Nothing official announced.

PELOSI THE POWERFUL -- While a wave of new members has supplied a Democratic majority and emboldened some in the replace-Pelosi camp, Democrats in California’s enlarged House delegation have largely embraced the election results as evidence of Pelosi’s prowess.

-- The morning after the election, Rep. Eric Swalwell was on national television lauding Pelosi’s strategy of emphasizing health care — an approach adopted by multiple triumphant California candidates — saying “this election was about health care, and Nancy Pelosi was the architect of the health care law. She helped hold Democrats together to stop it from being completely eviscerated.” Rep. Adam Schiff strongly tweeted his support, and so did Rep. Ro Khanna who argued that after the “blue wave” of the midterms, “to deny the first woman speaker who led us to that victory the gavel would be a slap in the face to the voters who sent us here."

-- SOME NEWCOMERS AGREE: Soon after their victories were official, two of the newest California Democrats — Reps.-elect Katie Hill and Mike Levin — released a joint statement backing Pelosi as the Democrat who could deliver on their campaign promises with “leadership that is bold, pragmatic and capable of swift results.”

-- As the jostling over the speakership intensified last week, Rep. Karen Bass quashed speculation that she could take on Pelosi with a terse tweet: “Nancy Pelosi has my vote for [s]peaker.”

-- BUT THEN THERE’S THIS...“Pelosi’s bid for speaker imperiled as public opposition grows: Sixteen Democrats released a letter promising to vote against the California Democrat on the House floor,’’ by POLITICO’s Rachael Bade, Heather Caygle and John Bresnahan: “The show of force underscores the depth of the challenge facing Pelosi, who has led the caucus for 16 years. Pelosi needs 218 votes among lawmakers present and voting to be elected speaker on Jan. 3. House Democrats have won 233 seats, meaning Pelosi can currently afford to lose only 15 votes.” Story.

-- THE ARGUMENT: “New House -- More Dems from California than from 36 other states combined,’’ via Washington Examiner: “Nearly 7 in 10 Democrats in the new House majority are from the East and West coasts, the latest sign of the party’s lack of connection with the heartland and South. And even more dramatic, there will be more Democratic members from liberal California than from 36 other states combined, according to an analysis from the bipartisan Washington firm Mehlman, Castagnetti, Rosen, and Thomas. “Democrats now dominate the coasts,” said the election analysis. Story.

-- “Nancy Pelosi’s Last Battle” by NYT’s Robert Draper: “As she prepares to lead the House of Representatives again, the most powerful Democrat in Washington will have to navigate between a rampaging president and her colleagues’ plans for fighting back.” Story .

THE MIDTERMS

-- LATEST VIA California Target Book Publisher Darry Sragow and senior researcher Rob Pyers:

-- HOUSE RACE GETTING TIGHT: Monday evening updates for CD-21 include about half of the 22,000 ballots that were outstanding in Kern County at the start of the day. Of those roughly 11,000, just over 3,000 were in the 21st and GOP Rep. David Valadao received only 30 percent of those. Valadao's district-wide margin over Democrat TJ Cox is now only 968 votes.

-- STATE SENATE: DEMS FLIPPED ANOTHER? In the Orange County-based state Senate District 34, Democratic former Assemblymember Tom Umberg was trailing Republican incumbent Janet Nguyen by close to 11,000 votes on election night. The latest returns have put him in front by 438 votes. If his lead holds, he will become the 29th Democrat, leaving the Republicans with only eleven members of the state Senate.

-- STATE ASSEMBLY: And in San Diego County's state Assembly District 77, Republican incumbent Brian Maienschein's lead has been cut to 2,563, a loss of 728 votes with Monday’s late update. With 112,000 San Diego county ballots outstanding and the 77th accounting for roughly 16 percent of registration in the county, that puts him into vulnerable territory. Currently, the Democrats have taken 60 of the 80 state Assembly seats.

CALIFORNIA ON FIRE

-- "79 Killed In Camp Fire As Number Of Missing Drops To 699,'' via NPR: The fire has burned about 151,000 acres and is 70 percent contained, as of Monday night. More than 4,700 workers are battling the flames. Authorities say they don't expect the fire to be fully contained until Nov. 30. Story.

-- DEEP DIVE -- from Bay Area News Group’s Pulitzer Prize-winner Mathias Gafni in Pulga: “PG&E transmission line eyed in Camp Fire had collapsed during 2012 storm” -- In December 2012, a fierce winter storm toppled five steel towers that support the same PG&E transmission line that malfunctioned minutes before the Camp Fire roared to life.

-- Now, six years later, the 115,000-volt Caribou-Palermo transmission line near Poe Dam and the tiny resort town of Pulga is again under the microscope. PG&E reported damage to it around 6:15 a.m. Nov. 8, about 15 minutes before flames were first reported under the high-tension wires, according to a regulatory filing and firefighter radio traffic. Another transmission line in nearby Concow also malfunctioned a half hour later, possible sparking a second fire. Story.

-- “Power companies must fireproof their equipment, but it won’t be cheap—and customers may pay,’’ by CALMatters’ Julie Cart: “California's increasingly dire blazes have brought a reckoning over the role of power equipment in starting wildfires." Story.

-- "CAN PG&E SURVIVE THE CAMP FIRE?" by SFChronicle’s J.D. Morris: “The stock price decline, which wiped out billions of dollars in shareholders’ wealth, came amid concerns from investors about PG&E’s potential liability in the horrific Camp Fire, which has far exceeded any other wildland inferno in state history as measured by lives lost and structures incinerated.” Story .

-- CAL MATTERS’ BEN CHRISTOPHER -- “California isn't built for 21st century wildfires—here's what the state could do about that” -- “Large swaths of California's population may eventually find themselves living in high-fire-risk areas as the climate changes. Lawmakers in Sacramento face a dilemma: impose costly and politically unpalatable regulations on homeowners and rip up existing infrastructure—or simply accept the risk.” Story.

-- NEW TOOLS -- “California Firefighters Use Supercomputers to Forecast Wildfires,’’ by KQED’s Jasmine Garnett: “The deadly blazes burning in California have put a spotlight on the crucial role of evacuation. To save lives and property, firefighters must predict where a fire will spread within moments after it starts. Now, California firefighters are getting some help from a powerful new tool: supercomputers.’’ Story.

title: Military backpedals on winding down border mission
description: "No specific timeline for redeployment has been determined," a spokesman for the Army component of U.S. Northern Command said.
content: Soldiers from the Kentucky-based 19th Engineer Battalion install barbed-wire fences on the banks of the Rio Grande on Nov. 18, 2018. | Thomas Watkins/AFP/Getty Images The military backpedaled Tuesday on the declaration by the general overseeing the deployment… [+2644 chars]
fulltext:
Soldiers from the Kentucky-based 19th Engineer Battalion install barbed-wire fences on the banks of the Rio Grande on Nov. 18, 2018. | Thomas Watkins/AFP/Getty Images immigration Military backpedals on winding down border mission

The military backpedaled Tuesday on the declaration by the general overseeing the deployment to the U.S.-Mexico border that some of his 5,800 troops would begin heading home in the coming days.

“No specific timeline for redeployment has been determined,” a spokesman for the Army component of U.S. Northern Command said in an emailed statement. “We will provide more details as they become available.”

Story Continued Below

Lt. Gen. Jeffrey Buchanan, who is overseeing the controversial deployment of active-duty troops to shore up border entry points, told POLITICO in an interview Monday that he expected to send the first wave of troops home later this week after they completed stringing concertina wire and building base camps.

“You’re going to see a couple of things over the next week — some redeployments,” said Buchanan, who heads the Army component and leads the active-duty border mission that President Donald Trump ordered. He cited “excess capacity” of engineers and logistics troops.

“By Christmas, it should be all,” Buchanan added. “Our end date right now is 15 December, and I’ve got no indications from anybody that we’ll go beyond that.”

But Tuesday, Buchanan’s headquarters cast that timeline in doubt, emphasizing instead that some troops will be shifted from Texas to California as the caravans of northward-bound migrants through Mexico shift direction.

“We may shift some forces to other areas of the border to engineering support missions in California and other areas,” the statement said. Migrants on Monday forced the partial closure of a main entry point.

Morning Shift newsletter Get the latest on employment and immigration, every weekday morning — in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

In the interview, Buchanan said that “the actual behavior of the caravans is more and more headed toward Tijuana, so while I’ve got to keep some forces in Texas, I’ve now shifted my main effort to California."

But the general’s assertion Monday that the mission was winding down — and that some troops would be coming home as early as this week — prompted renewed criticism from leading critics of Trump's snap decision to send the troops to the border before the election.

The brief statement from U.S. Army North on Tuesday, however, stated in full: "We are continually assessing our resources and refining requirements in close coordination with the Department of Homeland Security. We may shift some forces to other areas of the border to engineering support missions in California and other areas. No specific timeline for redeployment has been determined. We will provide more details as they become available."

title: The Bernie Sanders-Trump mind meld on drug costs
description: The bill, sponsored by Sen. Bernie Sanders and Rep. Ro Khanna, is sure to face stiff opposition from the drug industry.
content: Both Sen. Bernie Sanders and the president are embracing the idea of indexing U.S. drug prices to the lower prices paid by other countries in effect, relying on price controls set by other countries. | Rich Pedroncelli/AP Photo Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Dona… [+6681 chars]
fulltext:
Both Sen. Bernie Sanders and the president are embracing the idea of indexing U.S. drug prices to the lower prices paid by other countries — in effect, relying on price controls set by other countries. | Rich Pedroncelli/AP Photo Health Care The Bernie Sanders-Trump mind meld on drug costs

Sen. Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump are on the same page on drug pricing once again.

A bill released Tuesday morning by Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) to reduce U.S. drug prices takes a cue from the president’s recent proposal to reduce Medicare drug costs — both proposals seek to lower U.S. drug costs by tying them to international prices.

Story Continued Below

It’s the latest alignment on drug prices by populist politicians on opposite sides of the aisle. During their 2016 presidential campaigns, both Sanders and Trump advocated for negotiating the cost of drugs in Medicare and importing cheaper drugs from overseas. Now, they’re embracing the idea of indexing U.S. prices to the lower prices paid by other countries — in effect, relying on price controls set by other countries.

The proposed legislation stands almost no chance of gaining traction in a Republican-controlled Senate and is sure to face stiff opposition from the drug industry. But its similarities to Trump’s far narrower proposal for drugs administered as part of the Medicare Part B program speaks to the mounting pressure on both parties to address drug costs.

“I think the fact that everyone is discussing this — and you can’t escape it — suggests there will be action,” although not necessarily on these proposals, said Zeke Emanuel, a former Obama administration health adviser now at the University of Pennsylvania.

Prescription Pulse A weekly briefing on pharmaceutical policy news — in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Sanders and Khanna’s bill would incentivize drug companies to charge prices in the U.S. that are comparable to those paid in countries like Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany, France and Japan. If the companies don’t cooperate, the federal government could intervene to allow generic companies to produce cheaper knockoffs.

The legislation comes just a few weeks after Trump unveiled his own plan to overhaul how Medicare Part B pays for drugs by slowly tying payments for physician-administered drugs to international prices. The administration says it will release a proposed rule for the pilot project in early 2019.

Khanna told POLTICO that one of the reasons he and Sanders are rolling out their approach now is to piggyback on Trump’s proposal. But the lawmakers would take the idea of using international reference pricing much further — applying it to the entire U.S. market, not just to one part of Medicare.

“The president has given this window, and I think it is really important to do this in the lame-duck [session] — to say, ‘If the president is serious about this, he can endorse the proposal,’” Khanna said.

“It definitely invites Donald to put his policy where his mouth is,” said Alex Lawson, executive director of Social Security Works, a left-leaning group that works to safeguard Social Security, when asked whether this is a bill Trump might be able to support.

Health policy experts said one reason Trump, Sanders and Kahanna are drawn to the idea of international reference pricing is that it’s an easy policy to explain to the public. It is, for all intents and purposes, another form of government price-setting, but it allows politicians to avoid saying they want the U.S. government to set the prices of medicines — a policy reviled by drug companies and, traditionally, by many Republicans as well.

While some may see international reference pricing as “super left-wing,” that’s not really the case, said Peter Bach, director of the Memorial Sloan Kettering Center for Health Policy and Outcomes and a former Medicare and Medicaid official under George W. Bush.

Governments typically regulate prices set by monopolies, such as those given to brand drug companies, he said.

“I do think it’s fundamentally been a blind spot for us that we grant monopolies for drugs, and we do nothing about companies taking advantage of that monopoly,” Bach said. “It’s a fairly reasonable policy to say, ‘We will grant you a monopoly. We will grant it to you for ‘x’ number of years and we will let you charge a lot of money for it. But there will be a limit.’”

But critics on both the left and right of the proposals by the lawmakers and Trump wondered why the U.S., as the world’s largest market for drugs, would rely on other countries’ price controls rather than setting its own.

“One question … is why would the U.S. outsource our determination of the right price to other countries and not just make an independent assessment ourselves?” Emanuel said. “Why do we think Canada and Germany [are] better than we are at determining the right price?”

Ben Ippolito, who works on health economics at the free-market think tank American Enterprise Institute, had a harsher assessment: “It certainly feels like even Bernie Sanders doesn’t want to talk too much about actually setting prices; instead we’d like to back our way into it,” he said. But “if you really want to regulate prices at the federal government, then just regulate prices.”

The drug industry, meanwhile, panned the legislation before it was formally unveiled.

“This legislation would have the same devastating impact on patients as the administration’s proposed International Pricing Index model,” said Nicole Longo, spokesperson for the drug industry trade group PhRMA. “Patients in countries whose governments set prices wait years for new medicines and have far fewer treatment options. These policies reduce investment in research and development, slow progress in creating tomorrow’s cures and will result in Americans having access to fewer new medicines.”

Sanders and Khanna will formally introduce the legislation in the next Congress, but say they are putting it out now to help set the agenda for the next Congress, in which House Democrats plan to make drug pricing a top priority.

If their bill were to become law, they say, the median price of brand name prescription drugs could go down by more than 40 percent. For example, GlaxoSmithKline’s asthma medicine Advair Diskus, which currently costs about $390 for a 30-day supply, could drop to $222, based on the prices paid in the five countries outlined in the bill. Lantus, an insulin made by Sanofi, could cost $220 for a 30-day supply, down from $387, based on what other countries pay.

Despite Trump and Sanders getting on the same page, many conservatives think the Republican Party will not back international reference pricing approaches to drug costs.

“I just don’t see a swell of support for this,” said Doug Holtz-Eakin, president of the conservative American Action Forum. “This is tantamount to bringing to the U.S. price controls … and conservative aren’t fond of it.”
